canvas_summaries.ocr_text: UNTID: 113 WAR BROUGHT EQUAL WORK TO WOMEN MAKE PEACE BRING EQUAL PAY! Looking in from the outside- Britain lags behind her Allies in the economic treatment of her women! Yet - a quick probe into party policies reveals equal pay, or the- rate- for- the- job, as prominent in each party' s Post- war programme. In the coming switch- over from war to peace, industrial estimates give five million-- of the present working eight million-- as the starting figure for women who will be forced to earn their own living. Even that estimate does not allow for all those who will have to be the chief wage- earner in their family as a result of the war! A Royal Commission is considering the " problem " of equal- pay at the moment. In the past thirty years, two Royal Commissions have considered equal pay, but after wards nothing was put into effect! WHAT WILL HAPPEN THIS TIME?

ocr_allcaps: WAR BROUGHT EQUAL WORK TO WOMEN MAKE PEACE BRING EQUAL PAY

canvas_summaries.ocr_text: Equal Pay is proved and What must AMERICA think of us? In the U. S. A. women civil servants are paid exactly the same rates as their men colleagues, wherever appointments are identical. The same rule applies to women in the Services- Wacs, Waves, and the women Marines receive the same rank, pay, and allowances as their men. The same holds generally for women in industry. Five States have equal- pay laws in America- Michigan, Montana, Washington, Illinois, and New York. In other States the principle is followed locally by custom rather than by law. At the International Labour Office Conference at Phila delphia in May, 1944, British employer delegates tried to sidetrack the equal- pay clauses for post- war employ ment. But America and the other countries stood firm and held a united front. HERE ARE OTHER COUNTRIES WHERE TURKEY- In the year 1932, Turkish women received full emancipation. Equal pay is practised through out Turkey, and women work in full freedom and opportunity with men. BRAZIL At the L. L. O. Conference in May, 1944, the Brazilian Government adviser stated that Brazilian legislation provides for full equality for men and women workers.

canvas_summaries.ocr_text: practised in other countries What must RUSSIA think of us? In the U. S. S. R., women have exactly the same opportunities and are paid the same rates as their men colleagues. The rate is given – for the job. In a recent speech, Sir Stafford Cripps spoke of Soviet women and their success in national life as follows:-- " The Soviet constitution reflects the view throughout that women should have complete equality with men, but this of course would mean nothing unless that equality had been imple mented throughout the whole life of the Soviet Union... three out of every five Soviet women are now engaged in Industry of one kind or another. In 1941, 45% of the total number of workers of all grades in Industry were women... there is no distinction in their status or in their remuneration, they are in every sense equal to the men... It has been estimated of Britain' s women engaged in war production that about half of the war supplies sent to the Forces are produced by woman- labour. Why should employers be allowed to pay less for their services and so undercut men? For the immediate post- war period, the threat to men' s employment may be serious unless equal pay is established. THEY PRACTISE EQUAL PAY CANADA – one of our own Dominions- pays civil servants exactly the same rates- men and women- for CUBA — the same work. MEXICO-- DENMARK JUGO- SLAVIA- are all countries which allow women full rates of pay with men for doing the same work,

canvas_summaries.ocr_text: IN BRITAIN- EQUAL PAY IS DECLA THE CONSERVATIVE PARTY Recent publications issued by this party show equal status and equal pay to be defined in Conservative plans. for post- war Britain. From the report by the Conserva tive Sub- Committee on Industry--" WORK- The Future of British Industry " – the following extract is taken: " In the long run we do not believe that any indus trial difference of treatment between men and women could or should be sustained solely on the ground of difference in sex. If they are doing equal work, their remuneration should be equal." — Para. 57, page 19. THE LABOUR PARTY There is little need to prove the policy of equal status and equal pay for the Labour programme. To quote from" THE LABOUR PARTY TO- DAY " by Mary Agnes Hamilton: " Labour as a political party was the first to make the full emancipation, political, social, and economic, of women part and parcel of its fighting programme.".. At the WOMEN' S TRADE UNION CONGRESS 14th Annual Conference held at Leicester, October 27th and 28th, 1944, the following Resolution was among those passed, as submitted by the different Unions repre sented, after the initial welcome by Mr. Ebby Edwards, Chairman of the Trades Union Congress General Council:-- From the Clerical& Administrative Workers' Union " That this Conference notes the many expressions of appreciation which have been voiced by repre sentative members of the Government in regard to the services of women during the war; it therefore, urges the Government to translate these sentiments into reality by introducing equal salary standards for men and women in their employ, performing comparable clerical and administrative work."...

ocr_allcaps: EQUAL PAY IS DECLA THE CONSERVATIVE PARTY

canvas_summaries.ocr_text: CLARED POLICY FOR ALL PARTIES really to' h" the new e and THE LIBERAL PARTY Also stands for equal status and pay. In the latest issue of the Women' s Liberal Federation, WWOMEN' S WORK AND POSITION IN THE STATE, Section 1, comes the following: . " It seems essential, if the new social order after the war is really to be based on the principles of justice and Democracy, that, both for their own sakes and for the sake of the community, women should have a fair deal as citizens and workers, and not be the object of any discrimination on their sex. ".. From the section dealing with the economic status of women this conclusive statement appears: " Women as workers, whether in professions, the public service, trade or industry, should get the rate for the job; no facilities for training, no opportunity of learning professional or trade secrets, no avenue of promotion, no trade or process should be closed to them. No artificial and arbi trary division of work in factory or office into ' men' s work and women' s work' should be tolerated.... The Trades Unions should recognise the importance of protecting the right of women to equality of pay and opportunity as workers, since women' s rights and needs are the same as men' s. The interests of the whole of labour demand this, since unorganised and underpaid workers are too often used to lower the whole standard.'. THE COMMUNIST PARTY and THE COMMON WEALTH PARTY — also come out in full favour of the principle of equal pay. INDIVIDUALLY- All parties say they stand for it! WHICH PARTY is going to be the first to translate WORDS into DEEDS? Or

ocr_allcaps: S WORK AND POSITION IN THE STATE

canvas_summaries.ocr_text: EQUAL PAY OPINIONS AND INFLECTIONS From JACK TANNER, President of the Amalgamated Engineering Union: ... " There can be no moral or ethical justification against this claim for equal pay. There should be no economic discrimination against women, if they can do the job as well as men. I' m all in favour of equal pay for equal work, that is, the rate for the job, and it also is the policy of my Union, which, since January of last year( 1943) opened its ranks to women. " From GODFREY BOSTOCK, a manufacturer from the Midlands, in a broadcast in 1944: "... Speaking as an employer, the issue seems fairly clear, equal pay should be given for equal work." From LORD TRENT, at a London Conference of directors of Industrial concerns from all parts of Britain, this Summer: " Women have done a remarkable job. I am not going into the question of equal pay, but we have to recognise the fact that they will succeed in Industry. We had better accept that and give in gracefully."...

canvas_summaries.ocr_text: From CANDIDUS of the " Daily Sketch," in an article entitled " Justice to Women ": " The rate for the job seems so obviously fair a principle that one wonders that any opponent of it is audacious enough to raise his voice. After all, when it comes to paying rates and taxes a woman is not advantaged in virtue of her sex. Why should she be penalised for it when she is being paid instead of doing the paying? ". From MANNING DACEY, Financial Editor, in " The Observer," issue dated Sunday, April 22nd, 1944, under the heading" Women have a strong case on Equal Pay ": " To an economist, the only surprising thing about a demand for Equal pay for equal work is the idea that it is necessary to fight for it; in a free market it would happen automatically. After all, if men and women are really doing equal work, why should anybody continue to employ a man at higher wages when a woman would do the work equally well for less' money? In practice, a possible answer would be prejudice and tradition.". WIE LET' S SCRAP SEPARATE WAGE SCALES BASED ON SEX

canvas_summaries.ocr_text: From MRS. MAVIS TATE, M. P., Chairman of the Equal Pay Campaign Committee, speaking on equal pay as a principle: " This question must be judged, not on whether it will benefit one sex or one section of the one sex, but on whether it will be generally beneficial. Surely the principle of equal pay for equal work is right and just, and, if so, it will be found to benefit the whole community.... None of us who strive for equality wish to see women paid at men' s rates unless they' re actually doing as much and as good work. One benefit of equal pay will be that it will enable employers and employees alike to discover exactly what work is most suited to both sexes, because people will be engaged for their suitability for the job, and not because they are cheap labour ... " Women are not asking only for benefits, they are asking to be permitted to make a full contribution to the post- war world in partnership with men... there is no partnership unless there is equal status. Women in the home, too, would have an entirely different status if equal pay is granted.... Equal pay will enormously improve the position of the housewife and increase the importance of the home. A man will realise that a woman can earn a good living on her own and that if she gives it up it is because she would rather look after him and rear his children. I think she will take more trouble to prove it worth her while. " Issued by the Equal Pay Campaign Committee, 4, Ashley Place, S. W. 1 Speedee Press Services Ltd.( T. U. all depts.), 27A, Pembridge Villas, W. 11.

manifest_text:
UNTID: 113 WAR BROUGHT EQUAL WORK TO WOMEN MAKE PEACE BRING EQUAL PAY! Looking in from the outside- Britain lags behind her Allies in the economic treatment of her women! Yet - a quick probe into party policies reveals equal pay, or the- rate- for- the- job, as prominent in each party' s Post- war programme. In the coming switch- over from war to peace, industrial estimates give five million-- of the present working eight million-- as the starting figure for women who will be forced to earn their own living. Even that estimate does not allow for all those who will have to be the chief wage- earner in their family as a result of the war! A Royal Commission is considering the " problem " of equal- pay at the moment. In the past thirty years, two Royal Commissions have considered equal pay, but after wards nothing was put into effect! WHAT WILL HAPPEN THIS TIME?
Equal Pay is proved and What must AMERICA think of us? In the U. S. A. women civil servants are paid exactly the same rates as their men colleagues, wherever appointments are identical. The same rule applies to women in the Services- Wacs, Waves, and the women Marines receive the same rank, pay, and allowances as their men. The same holds generally for women in industry. Five States have equal- pay laws in America- Michigan, Montana, Washington, Illinois, and New York. In other States the principle is followed locally by custom rather than by law. At the International Labour Office Conference at Phila delphia in May, 1944, British employer delegates tried to sidetrack the equal- pay clauses for post- war employ ment. But America and the other countries stood firm and held a united front. HERE ARE OTHER COUNTRIES WHERE TURKEY- In the year 1932, Turkish women received full emancipation. Equal pay is practised through out Turkey, and women work in full freedom and opportunity with men. BRAZIL At the L. L. O. Conference in May, 1944, the Brazilian Government adviser stated that Brazilian legislation provides for full equality for men and women workers.
practised in other countries What must RUSSIA think of us? In the U. S. S. R., women have exactly the same opportunities and are paid the same rates as their men colleagues. The rate is given for the job. In a recent speech, Sir Stafford Cripps spoke of Soviet women and their success in national life as follows:-- " The Soviet constitution reflects the view throughout that women should have complete equality with men, but this of course would mean nothing unless that equality had been imple mented throughout the whole life of the Soviet Union... three out of every five Soviet women are now engaged in Industry of one kind or another. In 1941, 45% of the total number of workers of all grades in Industry were women... there is no distinction in their status or in their remuneration, they are in every sense equal to the men... It has been estimated of Britain' s women engaged in war production that about half of the war supplies sent to the Forces are produced by woman- labour. Why should employers be allowed to pay less for their services and so undercut men? For the immediate post- war period, the threat to men' s employment may be serious unless equal pay is established. THEY PRACTISE EQUAL PAY CANADA one of our own Dominions- pays civil servants exactly the same rates- men and women- for CUBA the same work. MEXICO-- DENMARK JUGO- SLAVIA- are all countries which allow women full rates of pay with men for doing the same work,
IN BRITAIN- EQUAL PAY IS DECLA THE CONSERVATIVE PARTY Recent publications issued by this party show equal status and equal pay to be defined in Conservative plans. for post- war Britain. From the report by the Conserva tive Sub- Committee on Industry--" WORK- The Future of British Industry " the following extract is taken: " In the long run we do not believe that any indus trial difference of treatment between men and women could or should be sustained solely on the ground of difference in sex. If they are doing equal work, their remuneration should be equal." Para. 57, page 19. THE LABOUR PARTY There is little need to prove the policy of equal status and equal pay for the Labour programme. To quote from" THE LABOUR PARTY TO- DAY " by Mary Agnes Hamilton: " Labour as a political party was the first to make the full emancipation, political, social, and economic, of women part and parcel of its fighting programme.".. At the WOMEN' S TRADE UNION CONGRESS 14th Annual Conference held at Leicester, October 27th and 28th, 1944, the following Resolution was among those passed, as submitted by the different Unions repre sented, after the initial welcome by Mr. Ebby Edwards, Chairman of the Trades Union Congress General Council:-- From the Clerical& Administrative Workers' Union " That this Conference notes the many expressions of appreciation which have been voiced by repre sentative members of the Government in regard to the services of women during the war; it therefore, urges the Government to translate these sentiments into reality by introducing equal salary standards for men and women in their employ, performing comparable clerical and administrative work."...
CLARED POLICY FOR ALL PARTIES really to' h" the new e and THE LIBERAL PARTY Also stands for equal status and pay. In the latest issue of the Women' s Liberal Federation, WWOMEN' S WORK AND POSITION IN THE STATE, Section 1, comes the following: . " It seems essential, if the new social order after the war is really to be based on the principles of justice and Democracy, that, both for their own sakes and for the sake of the community, women should have a fair deal as citizens and workers, and not be the object of any discrimination on their sex. ".. From the section dealing with the economic status of women this conclusive statement appears: " Women as workers, whether in professions, the public service, trade or industry, should get the rate for the job; no facilities for training, no opportunity of learning professional or trade secrets, no avenue of promotion, no trade or process should be closed to them. No artificial and arbi trary division of work in factory or office into ' men' s work and women' s work' should be tolerated.... The Trades Unions should recognise the importance of protecting the right of women to equality of pay and opportunity as workers, since women' s rights and needs are the same as men' s. The interests of the whole of labour demand this, since unorganised and underpaid workers are too often used to lower the whole standard.'. THE COMMUNIST PARTY and THE COMMON WEALTH PARTY also come out in full favour of the principle of equal pay. INDIVIDUALLY- All parties say they stand for it! WHICH PARTY is going to be the first to translate WORDS into DEEDS? Or
EQUAL PAY OPINIONS AND INFLECTIONS From JACK TANNER, President of the Amalgamated Engineering Union: ... " There can be no moral or ethical justification against this claim for equal pay. There should be no economic discrimination against women, if they can do the job as well as men. I' m all in favour of equal pay for equal work, that is, the rate for the job, and it also is the policy of my Union, which, since January of last year( 1943) opened its ranks to women. " From GODFREY BOSTOCK, a manufacturer from the Midlands, in a broadcast in 1944: "... Speaking as an employer, the issue seems fairly clear, equal pay should be given for equal work." From LORD TRENT, at a London Conference of directors of Industrial concerns from all parts of Britain, this Summer: " Women have done a remarkable job. I am not going into the question of equal pay, but we have to recognise the fact that they will succeed in Industry. We had better accept that and give in gracefully."...
From CANDIDUS of the " Daily Sketch," in an article entitled " Justice to Women ": " The rate for the job seems so obviously fair a principle that one wonders that any opponent of it is audacious enough to raise his voice. After all, when it comes to paying rates and taxes a woman is not advantaged in virtue of her sex. Why should she be penalised for it when she is being paid instead of doing the paying? ". From MANNING DACEY, Financial Editor, in " The Observer," issue dated Sunday, April 22nd, 1944, under the heading" Women have a strong case on Equal Pay ": " To an economist, the only surprising thing about a demand for Equal pay for equal work is the idea that it is necessary to fight for it; in a free market it would happen automatically. After all, if men and women are really doing equal work, why should anybody continue to employ a man at higher wages when a woman would do the work equally well for less' money? In practice, a possible answer would be prejudice and tradition.". WIE LET' S SCRAP SEPARATE WAGE SCALES BASED ON SEX
From MRS. MAVIS TATE, M. P., Chairman of the Equal Pay Campaign Committee, speaking on equal pay as a principle: " This question must be judged, not on whether it will benefit one sex or one section of the one sex, but on whether it will be generally beneficial. Surely the principle of equal pay for equal work is right and just, and, if so, it will be found to benefit the whole community.... None of us who strive for equality wish to see women paid at men' s rates unless they' re actually doing as much and as good work. One benefit of equal pay will be that it will enable employers and employees alike to discover exactly what work is most suited to both sexes, because people will be engaged for their suitability for the job, and not because they are cheap labour ... " Women are not asking only for benefits, they are asking to be permitted to make a full contribution to the post- war world in partnership with men... there is no partnership unless there is equal status. Women in the home, too, would have an entirely different status if equal pay is granted.... Equal pay will enormously improve the position of the housewife and increase the importance of the home. A man will realise that a woman can earn a good living on her own and that if she gives it up it is because she would rather look after him and rear his children. I think she will take more trouble to prove it worth her while. " Issued by the Equal Pay Campaign Committee, 4, Ashley Place, S. W. 1 Speedee Press Services Ltd.( T. U. all depts.), 27A, Pembridge Villas, W. 11.

text_summaries.summary:
In 1941, 45% of the total number of workers of all grades in Industry were women... there is no distinction in their status or in their remuneration, they are in every sense equal to the men...
In the latest issue of the Women' s Liberal Federation, WWOMEN' S WORK AND POSITION IN THE STATE, Section 1, comes the following: . "
From LORD TRENT, at a London Conference of directors of Industrial concerns from all parts of Britain, this Summer: " Women have done a remarkable job.
From CANDIDUS of the " Daily Sketch," in an article entitled " Justice to Women ": " The rate for the job seems so obviously fair a principle that one wonders that any opponent of it is audacious enough to raise his voice.
One benefit of equal pay will be that it will enable employers and employees alike to discover exactly what work is most suited to both sexes, because people will be engaged for their suitability for the job, and not because they are cheap labour ... " Women are not asking only for benefits, they are asking to be permitted to make a full contribution to the post- war world in partnership with men... there is no partnership unless there is equal status.

subjects_possible: Equal pay for equal work--Great Britain.
Equal pay for equal work--United States.
